audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker introducing himself and announcing the topic of the video: liquid carbon for aquariums. He then transitions to a more serious tone, addressing the YouTube community about comment legibility. This speech is followed by the distinct sound of a cowbell, accompanied by music. The music has a playful and catchy style, featuring upbeat drums and electronic elements.

The audio starts with a male speaker transitioning into a regularly scheduled program, describing liquid carbon and its relationship to Seachem's Flourish Excel and other versions. He conveys that he will be focusing on "what it is and how it works", answering that question in a mini-series; the first part will focus on "what liquid carbon is". He states that the next episode will dive into how it works, with the intention of understanding "what it's doing in our tanks". He wraps up by emphasizing the importance of understanding "what it is, how it works", and "what it's doing" when adding a chemical to a tank.

The audio clip begins with one male speaker starting to explain "liquid carbon" is "glutaraldehyde," then he clarifies by saying "what the heck is glutaraldehyde?". He then makes a humorous aside, mentioning "Dikembe Mutombo" in a lighthearted manner, followed by an unspecified sound.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker providing information on glutaraldehyde, discussing its use as a disinfectant and chemical sterilant. He notes its applications from medical equipment sanitation to industrial water treatment. He adds that an over-the-counter version is available for wart removal, ending the discussion with a playful remark about Jeopardy.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker introducing glutaraldehyde, emphasizing its non-corrosive properties and relevance to aquarium equipment. He explains the acidic nature of glutaraldehyde solutions, especially when purchased in bulk, and the purpose of the activator solution. The speaker clarifies that glutaraldehyde requires an alkalizing agent to activate and increase the PH, which helps to make it sporicidal. He also mentions that they discard this alkalizing agent and discusses the varying "day" versions available for purchase in bulk, elaborating on the period the solution remains activated after adding the agent. The segment concludes with the speaker highlighting the fact that these "day" variants do not matter as the activator is discarded.

A man speaks in an informative tone, explaining that the disinfectant activity of glute involves the "alkalation of sulfhydryl, hydroxyl, and carboxyl" and amino groups. He then simplifies the explanation, stating it alters the RNA, DNA, and protein synthesis of bacteria, affecting vital activities for life and reproduction, thus disinfecting things.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker introducing a discussion about safety when handling a certain substance. He clarifies that, although glutaraldehyde and formaldehyde belong to the same chemical class, their chemical and toxicological properties are significantly different, stating that glutaraldehyde does not contain or release formaldehyde and that there is "absolutely no evidence that it causes cancer". He goes on to say that products containing less than 50% of the substance are not considered environmentally dangerous and that even in concentrated form, the solution is only about 2.5%. He mentions a chart to illustrate the safety comparison of glutaraldehyde versus formaldehyde, concluding that in very dilute conditions, it's "relatively safe". The speaker then proceeds to other considerations before the clip ends. The man speaks in a calm, informative tone.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker, who explains that something is not dangerous to the environment, partly because it biodegrades quickly. He notes that this is why you have to dose liquid carbon often in your tank. He follows this by encouraging the listener to still be careful and take precautions when using glutaraldehyde, particularly concentrated solutions. The speaker lists precautions such as use in a well-ventilated area and avoiding contact with skin or clothing. He warns that failure to take these precautions can cause health problems. The speaker concludes by saying it's simple to take these precautions and the listener should just do it.

The clip starts with one male speaker discussing the dilution of a concentrated version of something, recommending going outdoors, using disposable gloves and goggles. He adds that some people might find that advice a bit scary, wondering whether it's safe to put the substance in a fish tank. The speaker has a calm, informative tone.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker detailing the properties of a substance. He describes it as readily biodegradable, mineralizing into water and carbon dioxide, and unlikely to bioaccumulate in aquatic organisms. He also notes that it doesn't inhibit fish or crustacean reproduction, is degraded by UV light and oxidation, and doesn't act as an endocrine modulator, emphasizing its safety for animals. The speaker is delivering information in a clear, informative tone. The clip concludes with an expression of agreement.

The audio clip features one male speaker offering a tip, stating "another tip is if you ever do have to dispose of it." He continues by suggesting using sodium bisulfate to neutralize glutaraldehyde for safe disposal through the sewer system, speaking in a casual and informative tone.

A male speaker begins by addressing the audience, mentioning that they might check their "Excel bottles" for ingredients. He explains that ingredient lists, once including a difficult-to-pronounce chemical, are no longer readily available, mentioning that "Seachem keeps it all very secret." He adds, however, that the information can be found "with a little bit of investigation, you know, Google." His tone is casual and informative.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker wrapping up a science lesson and previewing the next episode, which will delve into how glutaraldehyde works. He concludes by reminding listeners to write legibly in the comments. The audio appears to contain only this single speaker, delivering the information in an informative tone.

The audio begins with a speaker, likely a male, giving a directive to "hit the like button" if the listener enjoyed the video and to "hit the dislike button" if they didn't. His tone is casual and conversational, reflecting a typical content creator's closing remarks. He remarks that it wouldn't be YouTube without at least one dislike, before signing off to catch the listener in the next video. Shortly after, instrumental hip-hop music begins. It has a chill, somewhat melancholic mood, with a steady, relaxed beat.
